â˜‘ Few Bugs (Need to crouch and jump to get on some platforms when it wasn't necessary)
â˜ Nothing

Gameplay
this game is an expansion pack for Half-Life, Opposing Force is a first-person shooter. The overall gameplay of Opposing Force does not significantly differ from that of Half-Life. Players are required to navigate through the game's levels, fight hostile non-player characters and solve a variety of puzzles to advance.

Review
What I like about this DLC the most is it's in the same timeframe as the orginal Half-Life and they managed to keep the same playing style. Very enjoyable just like Half-Life has always been.

Find Gordon Freeman 8.5/10
 
Rapid Shadow
726 produits enregistrÃ©s

3 personnes ont trouvÃ© cette Ã©valuation utile
0
RecommandÃ©
14.8 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 28 juin 2022
My previous review was rather negative, but after a second playthrough, nah man, this expansion's pretty good. I'm gonna use this review as a chance to confront my old one and see where I was wrong.

- "New enemy types are obnoxious bullet sponges in all the moments you want them not to be." Nah dude, just do what you did with HL1 and figure out what guns go well against what enemies.
- "The handheld barnacle barely gets any use" Okay, still true, but it lets you skip one of the least interesting chapters very easily. That's worth plenty in redeeming it.
- "It's easy to miss certain new weapons entirely with how out of your way you have to go to find them." Nope, I literally just played a section wrong. You have to deactivate that electric fence while getting the Desert Eagle (your first gun!!), not damage boost through it. I also think I did in fact get the Spore Launcher and just forgot about it entirely somehow.
- "The boss fight at the end plays like a Mario or Zelda boss--read into that what you will." Okay, still true, but Idk why I ever tried to paint this negatively. I love Mario and Zelda, dude. It just clashes a bit in a boomer shooter, perhaps.
- "What a dated notion, by the way, that G-Man needs to minimize witnesses as though his employers were the US government--clashes a bit with the enigmatic endgame of galactic proportions he clearly attends to from HL2 onwards, don't you think?" Also still true, but everyone knows by now not to think too hard about the canonicity of the expansions. With the exception of Blue Shift, you probably aren't playing them for story anyway.
- "Opposing Force emphasizes combat over puzzle-solving, and is less forgiving with ammo and recovery." I found on replay that it's actually fair enough with ammo and recovery, as long as you're smart with your use of them. And the combat's fun! Why complain?

Additional points that have helped turn me around on Op4:
-This expansion's take on an On A Rail section is far shorter and less convoluted than HL1's. So, you know, it's better.
-Unlike HL1 or the HL2 saga, you never lose your arsenal. Which is great, because it's kind of a way better arsenal than Gordon's.
-Your squadmates aren't necessarily that smart and it can feel like they're slowing you down. This is a good thing in disguise because killing them is a good source of ammo (or even an early M249) if you're in a pinch and removes the headache!
-Look Adrian, ropes! We can use these for big pits.

Lessons to be learned: Consider playing it on Easy first. Going in gung-ho into Normal difficulty without at least doing the Boot Camp first wasn't smart. Pace yourself with it, too--5 hours straight of combat-centric Half-Life is easy to feel burnout from afterwards.

I misjudged you, Opposing Force. You're the best expansion. You're even better than HL2 Episode One. And that's mainline!
 
AndrewNebz

0

A great expansion to Half-Life. I enjoyed playing from the perspective of one of the soldiers (Adrian Shepard) and what he went through in order to survive Black Mesa! The game itself, well, just like Half-Life, it has a good combination of puzzles, weapons, combat and story telling. This expansion is definitely worth the buy (even at $4.99) to continue enjoying the amazing Half-Life series.

My rating:

Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 28 fÃ©vrier 2011
Opposing Force is very enjoyable to play after Half-Life. It's neat to see more of what's going on at Black Mesa while Gordon Freeman is running loose.

Opposing Force retains the polish of the original Half-Life. It doesn't tell the same great story, but the puzzles are strong and it fleshes out the original nicely.

RecommandÃ©
5.6 h en tout
Ã‰valuation publiÃ©e le 13 juillet 2017
Great and hard Half-Life expansion. Includes New weapons like sniper rifle, wrench, gross "grappling hook", alien taser, Desert Eagle, "green balls" launcher, machine gun striaght out of movie Rambo or a device, which take you to the Xen right away. You're controlling Shephard. No, not Commander Shephard, Adrian Shephard - US Marine Corporal. You're seeing Half-life from the soldier's perspective. From start to finish - real interesting experience.

Hold on....
Living Multiplayer? From the DLC from 1999? That's really neat...
No more COD, time for Opposing Force!

Personally one of the best DLC I've ever played.
